\text{Using step 2, we can replace }x \,by \tan \frac{y}{3}\\
\Rightarrow x = \tan \frac{y}{3}\\
\text{Diffrentiating the above equation, we get}\\
\frac{d(x)}{dx}= \frac{1}{3} . \sec^2 \frac{y}{3} . \frac{d(y)}{dx}\\ \text{Rearranging above equation, we get}\\ \begin{align} \Rightarrow \frac{dy}{dx}&= \frac{3}{\sec^2 \frac{y}{3}}\\ &=\frac{3}{1 + \tan^2 \frac{y}{3}}\\ &=\frac{3}{1 + x^2}\\ \end{align}
